stem: A 45-year-old client is 24 hours post-craniotomy for a tumor resection. Based on the documentation in the Post-Craniotomy Drainage & Wound Log tab, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Assessment of post-operative surgical site.
Background: Right frontal lobe resection. Subgaleal drain in place.
Assessment: Client reports a 'constant drip' in the back of her throat and an increasing headache.
Recommendation: Inspection of dressing and pharynx.

tabs.title: Drainage & Wound Log
tabs.content:
Assessment ItemCurrent FindingInterpretation
Dressing StatusMoist with clear, halo-like borderSuspect CSF
Pharyngeal ExamClear, salty-tasting fluid dripping down throatPost-nasal leak
Halo Test (Bedside)Bloody center with clear rings on gauzePositive Halo
Glucose StripPositive for glucosePositive for CSF

actionOptions.text: Keep the head of the bed (HOB) elevated to 30 degrees
Notify the neurosurgeon immediately of the drainage findings
Instruct the client to blow their nose periodically to clear the drainage
Place a tight pressure dressing over the nose and throat

parameterOptions.text: Neurological status and Presence of Nuchal Rigidity (Meningitis risk)

rationale.correct: This client has a Post-Operative CSF Leak (c2), as evidenced by the 'Halo' sign on the dressing, clear 'salty' drainage in the throat, and positive glucose testing (since mucus usually doesn't contain glucose). A CSF leak is a major risk for meningitis. Priority actions are to promote drainage while maintaining low ICP (HOB 30 degrees) (a1) and notifying the surgeon for potential repair (a2). Key parameters: Neuro/Meningitis assessment (p1) and monitoring the drainage itself (p2).
clinicalPearls: The Halo Test: A drop of drainage on gauze; if blood stays in the center and a clear ring forms around it, it's CSF.
Never suction the nose or allow the patient to blow their nose if a CSF leak is suspected; it can increase pressure or introduce bacteria into the brain.
Clear drainage from the nose (Rhinorrhea) or ear (Otorrhea) after head trauma or brain surgery is CSF until proven otherwise.

questionTrap.trap: Instructing the patient to blow their nose to get a better sample.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Contraindicated! Do NOT shove anything into the nose or use pressure to clear it; this can cause air to enter the brain (Pneumocephalus).

mnemonic.title: CSF Check
mnemonic.expansion: C-Clear fluid. S-Salty taste. F-Font (Halo) ring.
